transcripts.text: Andrew in Ohio.  Hey, Andrew, what's going on?
Hey, how are you guys doing?  Doing fantastic.
How can we help?
I'm a Christian, and I believe the Bible is the word of God, and I think this assembly of writings in the Bible proves a supernatural God.  What are your thoughts about that?  Whoa.
Disagree, first off.  That's my first thought.  I'll be honest.  Yeah, so I don't know how the Bible proves the supernatural.
Do you think that God would use different authors over 1,500 years of time?

How much do you know about the authors and when the Bible was written?  I'm interested to know, Andrew, how much you've researched Bible scholarship and specifically what we know about when the Bible was written, who wrote it, and why they wrote it.  Have you looked into that?
I've studied a little of the skeptics, the Bart Ehrmans of the world.

Okay.  And so like you asked me why don't I or does God using multiple authors over 1,500 years convince me of the supernatural?  And I would say no because I don't believe God did that.  I just think multiple people just wrote about Judaism slash Christianity over 1,500 years.  I don't think there's any—you don't need the supernatural to write any of the things in the Bible.  I don't think that's required.
I'm not sure it was even 1,500 years.
I mean, I think that's my understanding.
It's about from—even the most, I think, skeptics would say from 1,400 B.C.  to about 95 A.D.  was when Revelation was— Yeah,
I don't quibble with that number, but—
I would quibble with it.  From what I understand, the first books of the Old Testament began to be written about 800-900 BC.  In fact, if you look on Wikipedia, that's pretty much what it says.

So, yeah, but I guess if we're OK, so I guess it'd be a shorter period of time is what you're saying.  I think that's I think that's a little more in the in the weeds there than maybe where I want to take this conversation.  I'm curious, Andrew, like what about the Bible?  that it convinces you that the beliefs or the claims in the Bible at least are true?  Like why?  Why do you come to that conclusion?
That he could use like a shepherd like Amos or a military general like Joshua.
Well, how do you know that God used these writers in the first place?
It says in Peter that he used the Holy Spirit through these writers to conceive this amazing book.
But how do you know that's true?  Like, how do you know the writer of Peter wasn't just making that up?

Because we have, well, we can go many different ways with this, but... Why do you think Christianity was created?  I guess the question I would ask you, do you think Jesus was a liar, lunatic, lord, or legend?
Well, I would love it if you could answer my question first, and then we can definitely talk about the trilemma there.
Can you ask that one more time?
Okay, so like the writer of 1 Peter who said all of the books of the Bible – I mean that's not what he says, right?  But like the authors of the scripture I believe is like the terminology there.
I think that 2 Timothy Paul wrote that all scripture is breathed by the Holy Spirit.
Yeah, it's through the Holy Spirit.  Like how do we know that that statement, that claim is true?  What are we using to know that that's true?
Well, we have multiple documents.  These are multiple writings we have.  So like the 27 documents of the New Testament, you don't think that was written by one writer?

No, no.  I think they're – I'm not disputing that they're written by multiple people.  What I am disputing is like how do we know that the Holy Spirit or God himself was involved with the creation of the Bible?
Because when you look at what – he gave us multiple manuscripts.
Who gave us multiple manuscripts?
What was that question?
Who gave us multiple manuscripts?
The people that were writing the New Testament and the Old Testament.
Okay.  So the people who are writing the New Testament and the Old Testament...
Scribes, whatever you want to call it.  Give us multiple manuscripts.
Okay.
So what?  Of all the books of antiquity, the New Testament has the most manuscripts.  Oh, okay.
So because out of all the books of antiquity, the New Testament has the most manuscripts, therefore God... use multiple authors to create the entire Bible?
Well, that's a fragment of evidence that we're using.  We're not looking for a grand slam argument here.
I know, I know, but you see how I'm not able to draw that conclusion based on what you're telling me here.
But when you understand history, in 303 AD, Diocletian the emperor was burning these scriptures.
But what does that have to do with God creating the Bible or being in charge of the authors of the Bible?

He is sovereign over all things.  So even in Jeremiah, when the king was burning that Jeremiah scroll, another one was created that we have in the Old Testament.  So even when people are trying to destroy the Bible, it will still... It will still survive.

You could say the same thing about almost any controversial book, that people are going to want to destroy it and others are going to want to salvage it.  It doesn't tell us anything about it being written by God or inspired by God.

Yeah.  Because I'll even go as far as this, Andrew.  Yeah, I agree with you.  I think that – I mean I think there's more manuscripts of the New Testament that we have than any other book in antiquity as far as I know.  I think that's true.  I still don't believe that God used multiple people to write the Bible though.  So that's not a part of my reasoning.
You're looking for more evidence, I guess, your question was.

I guess the fact that there's multiple authors of the Bible, one, I guess it doesn't impress me.  It doesn't confirm a belief that God is sovereign over all things one way or the other.  It doesn't really move me too much.
I guess the question would be why do you think Because Nero was persecuting the Christians within 30 years, so why do you think these are written down?  And they could be killed for writing.

Being persecuted means nothing.  Jehovah's Witnesses think that Russia is the king of the north, prophesied in Daniel, because Russia has recently banned Jehovah's Witnesses.  It doesn't make that true.  Just because Nero was persecuting a group doesn't mean that God inspired the texts that they follow.
Well, Christianity was a threat to the Roman Empire.

Maybe it wasn't, but that doesn't make it God's one true revelation to mankind.  I'm just dragging you back.  The reason why I asked you about scholarship, and I asked you this because I respect you, Andrew, and I'm sure that like me and Dan, you care about what's true.  And you're not going to want to waste your life on something if it's not true or if there's any kind of doubt about it.  Go on Wikipedia and Look up the title or the subject heading Dating the Bible.  And there's a table there, Table 1, Chronological Overview.  And it tells you the order in which scholars think the books of the Old Testament were written.  The oldest period in which the first books started to be written, according to Bible scholars who dedicate their careers to understanding this properly, is the monarchic period 745 BCE to 586 BCE.  So even more recent than I was suggesting off the top of my head earlier.  It turns out that when you actually study what the Old Testament says, it's clearly written in a far more recent period than it suggests.  Just one example, it describes Abraham riding around on camels at a period in history before, sorry, long before camels were domesticated.  But if the Bible was written in the first century, or sorry, in the first millennia BC, it would make far more sense for there to be characters riding around on camels.  Do you see what I'm saying?  So scholars are able to look at all of these different details and say, well, clearly, When we factor in all of these different things, clearly we can pinpoint a much later period for these books to have been written than the books themselves are suggesting.  And just because the book is saying something doesn't mean we should just accept it on face value.  Otherwise, we would all be Mormons and we would all believe what Joseph Smith was writing because why would he lie to us?  Yep.
Well, we can find evidence of the Old Testament.

Where's the evidence of the Israelites wandering in the wilderness?  Archaeologists have literally tried their very, very best to find even a toothpick that was left behind in the Sinai wilderness.  They haven't found a single thing.  There's no evidence of anything happening there.  that's described in the old testament.  beyond.  when you start seeing references to david and solomon in other words the monarchic period we have evidence for the kings.  we don't have evidence for the judges.  we don't have evidence for exodus.  we don't have evidence for the patriarchs.  we certainly don't have evidence for noah or adam and eve.  all of these things as far as we can tell are just completely made up fables.
So you don't believe the Old Testament.  So why do you think Christianity was created?

To control people.  And actually, we know more about the writers of the Old Testament than we know about the writers of the New Testament.  Did you know that the books Matthew, Mark, Luke and John are all given assigned names?  In other words, they're not literally written by Matthew, Mark, Luke and John.  They don't even say in the books, hey, I'm Matthew and I'm writing the book of Matthew.  They literally just chose names and gave them those names.  We have no idea who wrote Matthew.  We have no idea who wrote Mark.  And that makes total sense when you actually read the books and compare them next to each other and realize, hey, these books actually contradict each other and give varying accounts of the same thing, but with different things happening in those accounts.  And it all starts to make sense once you reach the obvious conclusion, hey, these books were written by humans.  Yeah.  And maybe they're not entirely truthful.

here's something i mean if you would ask me i would say christianity is jewish revisionism in the same way that mormonism is christian revisionism or that.  uh you know the beliefs of jehovah's witnesses are christian revisionism.  you know like christianity is taking a lot of the source material from judaism which is something that's been around but it's changing it on its head to where it's almost completely different.  jewish people don't recognize many of what christians believe despite the fact that the leader of that Christianity, that Jesus Christ, like, was a Jewish person and said that, you know, he was fulfilling that of the Old Testament and, you know, was making all these references that Jewish people would understand. there are no anonymous copies of the Gospels?  You think that at the top of each scroll it says Mark, Luke, and John in the original Greek?  It doesn't.

where does it say in the book of matthew?  hey i'm matthew and i'm writing this.

And all I'm suggesting is that there might be a gap in your knowledge.  that a little bit of reading up on Bible scholarship might fill.  You mentioned right at the outset that you've at least dabbled a little bit with Bart Ehrman by the sounds of things.  That's one scholar.  There are others.  And if you jump on Amazon and you look for a few different books, let me see, there's one book that I can recommend off my bookshelf.  This is a fantastic book that you might want to check out, The Bible Unearthed.  by Israel Finkelstein.  Israel Finkelstein is a leading archaeologist and he writes about the Bible lands and how how critics are able to reach conclusions about the Old Testament based on things that are described.  For example, the fact that if the Israelites had left Egypt to go and conquer the Promised Land, they would only have been conquering another part of Egypt because Palestine was part of Egypt in the time period that's described.  Things like that that you probably didn't know before.  you will learn by reading this and other books.  All I'm suggesting is learn more about what scholars have to say because they've dedicated their careers to understanding the Bible better.  They don't have a reason to lie to you.  They just want to know what's true.
